description.en:
The course covers:

* Digital evidence and its differences from traditional types of evidence.

* Use and preservation of digital evidence.

* Admissibility of digital evidence and tactical considerations.

* Computer forensics.

* True cybercrime - criminal activity inherently involving ICT (viruses, unauthorized access and data alteration).

* Cyberbullying and -stalking.

* Credit card fraud, identity theft and money laundering.

* Child pornography.

* Criminal procedure involving cybercrime and collection of evidence.
description.et:
Kursus katab järgnevad teemad:

* Digitaalsed tõendid ja nende erinevused klassikalistest tõenditest.

* Digitaalsete tõendite kasutamine ja säilitamine.

* Digitaalsete tõendite kogumine ja kasutamine kohtus.

* Küberkriminalistika.

* Küberkuritegevus.

objectives.en: This course explores technical and legal issues related to collection and use of electronic data as evidence in litigation. The course also examines the technical and legal aspects of criminal use of computers and networks.
objectives.et: Kursusel uuritakse tehnilisi ja õiguslikke probleeme, mis on seotud elektrooniliste andmete kogumise ning sellise teabe kohtumenetluses tõendusmaterjalina kasutamisega. Samuti uurib kursus arvutite ja arvutivõrkude kriminaalse kasutamise tehnilisi ja õiguslikke aspekte.

learning_outcomes.en:
Students:

* are familiar with general principles of digital evidence and can differentiate them from other types of evidence.

* understand how digital evidence is collected, analysed and used in court.

* know the process of handling digital evidence and are familiar with the tools and methods used by experts.

* can solve cases and analyse judicial decisions dealing with digital evidence.

* are familiar with general principles of computer forensics.

* understand the basic technical concepts of main types of cybercrime and main issues in cybercriminal law enforcement.

* can apply the rules of criminal procedure to a digital environment. 

* can identify and discuss problems arising of the intersection of IT, criminal activity and court procedure

Rewarded is:
1) Presenting your analysis in a structured and coherent manner;

grade_preconditions.et: Submitting the written case analysis and presenting it in seminar and active participation in homework discussion seminar.

grade_evaluation.et:
Final grade consists of:
1) Written case analysis and its discussion seminar (up to 25%);
2) Written closed-book exam with open-ended questions (up to 75%).

Minimum score of 51% for the written exam and a minimum total score of 51% is needed for a positive grade.

100-91 % - A
90-81 % - B
80-71 % - C
70-61 % - D
60-51 % - E
Less than 50 % - F

debt_elimination.et:
Homework must be submitted on time. Overdue work will not be accepted. Course work (homework, seminars) cannot be retaken.

In case of a negative grade the written exam can be retaken.
